description.text: A full length version of the MOD-T printing bed clips provides a stronger hold for the bed.

Printer:

MOD-t

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

15

comments.text: Great addition to try and help the printer not be completely trash. But the print shroud upgrade's vent hits them when it tries to do the whole cleaning strip thing. not too bad cause i can just let it calibrate, clean, pause it, put on the vent, and then let it work on the print itself.
comments.author: 256spam

comments.text: I ran into that problem as well, I just changed the length of the nozzle wipe in the cura start script.
comments.author: 256spam

comments.text: What length do you reccomend? Also looking at it i dont actually know what i should be changing to adjust it....
comments.author: Fidofetch

comments.text: Another note, I have had great luck with the fan housing. Seems to make for more consistent printing. Also made handle/hole covers. They look nicer than the tape I had over them.
comments.author: 3DPhotoDude

comments.text: I made the clips and yes the head hits the edge when it calibrates with Firmware 0.10.0 and Printer tool 1.5.3. The clip is tight so it does curl right above the notch, which make a bigger target for the extruder. Great idea, I have issues with the edge of the bed curving up slightly and causing long pieces to release on the ends. I tried Energywave's corner clips and they worked, haven't put them on lately. Had other issues and now can go back and test them. Thanks for your work.
comments.author: 3DPhotoDude

comments.text:
Hello Fidofetch, great rework of my clips! I'll try them as if they fit well they could solve the orthogonality problem of the bed as with the new calibration (FW 0.13, if I remember correctly) it could happen that MOD-t will hit too hard the bed to a wall going oblique, using my clips.
With your variation the bed will be hit as hard but the contact point will be both sides so the bed should not going oblique!
I was thinking about creating two other clips to apply on the other side of the bed but you arrived first ;)
Only one thing: it's a good idea to rename this objects because this is very different from the real "Mod_ski". I have seen the original object and is something totally different. I know they are working on making an instructable to publish the object and the instruction to build and mount the thing.
So if you don't rename this objects that could lead in confusion to people searching for it.
comments.author: energywave

comments.text: Thanks for the comment, I've renamed it. I've also noticed the issue of the clips being hit during calibration and have considered cutting a larger portion out of the inner wall of the clip but have not been able to test it yet.
comments.author: energywave

comments.text: Awesome, thanks!  What other mods do I see that you have on your print head?
comments.author: tjbarney

comments.text: I would also recommend these. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1219325
comments.author: tjbarney

comments.text: It's a cooling fan vent. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1529972
comments.author: tjbarney

comments.text: Thank you very much!
comments.author: Fidofetch

Mounting Bracket to Hold a LJC18A3-B-Z/BX Sensor
Suited to the Hotend Bracket of a Tronxy P802e from Aliexpress

Update
I have my probe working with Repetier Firmware and i thought i would post some notes given how little information there is on the Web.

LJC18A3-B-Z/BX Sensor Wiring
The Brown wire is +, Blue Wire is - and Black wire is Signal.
If using a Melzi board (like I am). I connect Brown to the 12V PSU +, Blue to PSU - and the Black Signal to the Z min endstop signal.

Repetier Firmware
I use Repetier firmware, please dont ask questions about Marlin as i have no idea.
Use the online tool https://www.repetier.com/firmware/v092/ to make changes to your firmware.
Make sure ALWAYS_CHECK_ENDSTOPS is set to false. This in on the Mechanics Tab.
On the Features Tab, enable Z-Probing and also set the method of Auto Bed leveling you want to use. I use n*n grid and set the grid to 4 (16 Z probe points). Leave the rest as default as you can set the Probe height, offsets and probe points in the eeprom.

I have my probe set to trigger when the nozzle is roughly 2mm above the print bed, so i have set my Probe height to 2mm.
To get the Z Probe value and you have a Z min end stop. Move the Nozzle so that the sensor is off your print bed and home Z so that it is just touching your print bed (manual calibration). Slowly move your nozzle so that the sensor is over the bed with the nozzle still touching the bed. Now move Z up 10mm and then send a G30 command to your printer. This is will return the value Z moved down when the probe was triggered, for example 8.23mm. Now subtract that value from 10mm. in my example 10- 8.23 would be 1.77mm. To be safe, set your Z probe Height in eeprom as 1.75 which gives 0.02mm clearance.

My Start G-Code is as follows.

G28 X0 Y0 ;Home X and Y
G1 Z10 F{Z_TRAVEL_SPEED} ;Move Z UP 10mm
G1 X150 Y150 F{TRAVEL_SPEED} ;Move X and Y to the centre of your print bed.
G28 Z0 ;Home Z (when the probe triggers it will then move down past the trigger point 2mm, as set as the probe height).
G1 Z10 F{Z_TRAVEL_SPEED} ;Move Z UP 10mm
G32 S2 ;Perform the auto levelling calibration

G32 S2 will store the calibration results in eeprom, which means if nothing changes, you dont have to perform the calibration everytime. And will remain after a Power Cycle. However, I like to run my calibration before everyprint, as i cannot guarantee that nothing has changed. It only takes a minute or two.

This is how i have setup my Prusa I3 Clone and it works for me. Warning, you may need to use different values. I hope at least some of this information helps somebody out - i know i would have liked to have known at least half of whats written here before i installed my probe - would have saved my me 2 days of yelling at my printer. Good luck

comments.text: Hi, srbaude86! Tell please, how you connected the sensor, directly, or through a resistive divider? The end stop switch of axis Z was deleted?
comments.author: arheep

comments.text:
No Resistors. Wired directly to 12V power supply. Then the signal Wire was connected to the Z-min signal pin. I also have the Z-min End stop connected to Z-min pin. I only had todo this with the Melzi board as it only has pins for XYZ Min. If you are using a RAMPS or other boards that has pins for both Z min and Z max, then you can wire the probe to Z max and use that pin.
In Firmware i Home XY then Home Z all to Min. And also set the Z probe pin to the Z-min Pin. This does not interfere with the programming as you are homing First then Probing the bed second. When Z homes, it should go lower than the bed height (yes the tool head may bump the bed but thats ok, you can fine tune this). Then the pin behaviour changes so you can use your Z probe.

remixed_from.author: dintid
remixed_from.title: Spoolholder with mount for 2020 Extrusion I-Type 5

title: Spool Holder inner part with end cap

description.text:
dintid's spool holder is really amazing and I was excited to build one out.

This remix only takes his inner screw part and lowers the bearing and nut down 16mm so that the nut ends up flush with the outside.

Then, I created and added an end cap to cover the bearing and nut.

The end nut can be printed in the same filament, different color, or for me - I did it in Ninja Semi-Flex.

This is only 1 part of the spool holder - you'll need the rest from here (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1000323)

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed these in eSun PETG @ 235* runing my fan @ 60% starting on the 4th layer.

The Ninja Semi-Flex was printed 230* and fan @100% starting on the 3rd layer.

You most likely will need supports for the lower bearing slot on the inner part.

Depending on your printer's resolution - you should be able to print both the inner part and the end cap without any scaling. I did have to up-scale my end cap using NinjaFlex.

I also printed these using a .6mm nozzle

Be sure to print this inner part and dintid's slimmed spoolholder nut at the same infill.
I used dintid's 3mm spacer between the mount nut and the lower bearing - this kept the spool close to my vslot, but gives enough room so as not to cause any issues.

Simply a shoe hanger for wet (or dry) shoes you don't want cluttering up the floor. I use these for drying my shoes (it's pretty snowy here in Denmark at the moment).
If you want to use these as a space saver in a closet, I included a hole to enable them to be stringed together (use thicker wood, they might get heavy with 5 or 6 pairs of boots adding up weight)...

You will have to adjust the size of the "horns" to accomodate smaller shoe sizes (these fit European ~size 38 or US size 6 & up).
Note that if you want to hang more than two pair of wet shoes together, you also might want to adjust the width of the top hangers, to keep water from one pair from dripping on the ones below).

title: Y Rod Bracket with trapped nut for Aluminum Mendel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I wasn't comfy with the drill/tap concept on printed parts for the original (and most excellent) Aluminum Mendel design. So I went ahead and started making some trapped nut versions of the affected parts. Hopefully, I'll find time to work out more trapped nut replacement derivatives soon... until then, here's the set of brackets that hold the Y axis smooth rods in place.

I've included STL files for both 8mm and 10mm smooth rods.  Setscrew/nut sizes in those STLs are #6/32 SAE.
These models are scaled around my printer's nuances, so salt the .scad source to your own taste.
The .scad file has source for both the regular and offset versions of the part.  Just change the boolean at the top of the file for desired output.  (and the other stuff too, if you've got #4/40 or metric and all that)

author: dbfrompw

title: Crock Pot Fan Mount for Vapor Smoothing

description.text:
Purchased a cheap $10 crock pot to use for vapor smoothing ABS prints and wanted to be able to circulate the air/vapor inside to ensure even coverage of the model. Designed this fan mount for a 30mm fan to fit in the existing grommet on the crock pot lid. Design allows for tilt and rotation, wires feed through the shaft of the mount. Works like a charm.

Assuming you're using acetone to smooth ABS it should go without saying but print this in something else (I did PLA) so it doesn't get dissolved itself.

Slow cooker I'm using is a Hamilton Beach 3 quart model currently on clearance at Best Buy: http://www.bestbuy.com/site/hamilton-beach-3-quart-slow-cooker/2926342.p?id=1219083561841&skuId=2926342 - I bought it through their eBay store and it shipped free. No affiliation.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.200

Infill:

15%
Screw the fan into the carrier, feed the wires through the hole in the mount and snap the two pieces of the mount together.

author: MVPrint

description.text: This is the peg for my Dial bracket mount. Find it here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1710968 This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dGolTsVC2ET

UPDATE 03/12/2017;

New Version;

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2171864

UPDATE 11/20;

A new design is on the way, thinner and better battery life. At the moment I am upgrading my printer, along with other life events, the upgrade is going slow. Hopefully in the next month or two, I will have the files for the new design finished.

UPDATE 9/11;

The batteries from ebay are a joke, I should have know that 6000 mAh battery for $1 was too good to be true. I charged the battery with a know good charger to 5000 mAh, which is the highest my charger will go. Attached a load, 50 ohm resistor, which equates to about 80 mA. The battery only lasted 12 hours before the voltage dropped to 2.8, which is the limit for LiPo's.....So new batteries are coming, which are thinner, so there will be an update to the case soon, stay tuned.

UPDATE:

This morning I completed a test of the battery capacity; Simply, Youtube videos on auto play. Results are as follows; CPU load approx. 35%, total run time 2 hours, when the batteries were depleted to 25% I ended the test.

Apparently, either the charger is not charging the batteries to full capacity, or the batteries do not have the capacity stated.

More investigation will be required, for the time being I cannot recommend the batteries or charger/booster until I determine what the problem is. I will post my results soon.

I apologize for the fish eye pics, I used my action camera and didn't think about the wide view.

Let's see, where do I start...............First off, tablets and smart phones are cool and all, but they don't cut it for those of us who like to tinker. I wanted something portable and flexible and reconfigurable; so when I came came across the Pocket PC, I thought, That's me!! But, Not quite what I am after. So here is my version, mind you, this is a prototype, and the final design can and will change soon.

Things needed for my version:

3D Printer (Duh!!)
Raspberry Pi 3 with OS
5" 800 x 480 HDMI LCD, or whatever the same size.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/221952432326?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

LiPo Batteries
http://www.ebay.com/itm/131557359557?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Battery Charger/Booster
http://www.ebay.com/itm/291653902869?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Wireless keyboard if you so desire, NOT BLUETOOTH!!!! Explanation later.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/151949670710?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Micro USB Cable, will be cut!!
HDMI Cable or HDMI Cable connectors
Soldering iron, and De-Soldering
2 x Female USB Sockets (Type A), I got mine from and old USB HUB
-Slide or toggle switch
Hot Glue
Thin CA Glue, super glue

Preparations:

-Remove R-Pi's USB Sockets, solder in the 2 single sockets on the forward pads.
-Remove Charger/Booster Type A USB Socket
-Removal of R-Pi's RJ-45 is not necessary, I had removed mine for another project, I will be adding it back later and adding provisions for it in the case.

-Remove housing and plastic from Keyboard receiver, solder ribbon or wire to receiver, solder to free USB pads, make sure to get Polarity Correct!! Cover with tape or heat shrink.

-Print Pocket PC, Hinge, Cover if you want

-Trim down USB cable, the micro end, cut off A plug, get the micro side as small as possible, careful not to cut any wires.

-Build HDMI Cable, I felt this is necessary because store bought cable are massive and will not fit, Google HDMI pin out, simple build, 1 -1, 2 - 2, and so on.

-Secure LCD in Bezel with hot glue tabs on back side, set aside.

-Connect batteries, Charge/Booster, switch, R-Pi, refer to schematic image (Apologies, I am not a graphic artist), leave enough length on wire for everything to fit. Caution, once you connect everything be careful not short anything.

-Secure R-Pi in case with some tiny screws, I got mine from old equipment and devices, no need to buy any if there is junk laying around.

-Secure batteries with hot glue tabs, secure switch and Charger/booster

-Glue on hinge, prop, and latch

All done, total cost, not including 3D printer;

Keyboard - $18
Batteries - $ 2
Charger/Booster - $ 5
LCD - $ 33
R-Pi - $ 35
Hardware - Free Salvage
Cables - Free Salvage

Total - $ 93

I am including all files, if someone makes an improvement or a cool feature let me know, and please give credit where credit is due. As mentioned earlier, this is a prototype.

I used 2 x 6000 mAh batteries, I estimate this should give the Pi 20 to 30 hrs run time, future test will verify.

DO NOT Use a Bluetooth keyboard, if for some reason you have to enter linux shell out side of X, you will not be able to use the keyboard, therefore the use of a standard wireless keyboard will work in the shell.

I will try to answer anyone's questions and help the best I can.

Side Note:

The Charger booster has to be activated once your switch is turned on, a simple matter of pressing the little switch on the board.

This version is about 35 mm thick, I am trying to source smaller batteries and make it thinner.

Printer:

Dup I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm

Infill:

35% to 50%, 100% on hinges

Notes:

Makergeek PETG, use a rim, 1 mm offset for priming nozzle

Nozzle - 240 C
Bed - 70 C

I have in the past couple weeks, been able get my printer and settings tuned for Makergeek PETG. You results may vary, but the PETG does not like too much heat; Cooling is required. I have very little strings, blobs and zits, and it bridges fairly well. Not much clean afterwards.
Autodesk 123D

description.text:
UPDATE 3-11-2017: Added "Hotend_Holder_adjustable.stl" and "left_mount.stl. Now you can level the hotends to the bed! The recesses for the left hotend have been deepened to allow for slight vertical travel up and down.

Upgrade your Replicator 2x's extruder using an E3D-v6 kit. This helps reduce the weight and drag on the x-carriage improving overall print quality. No physical modification of the x-carriage is required!

Parts:
2x E3Dv6 24v 1.75mm Kit (w Bowden add-on) see note at bottom.....!
2x 4mm Push In Joint Pneumatic Connector Quick Fittings (5mm Male Thread)
4x M3 x 25 Hex-Head Socket Cap Screws
4x M3 Washers
4x M3 x 8 Hex-Head Socket Cap Screws
2x M3 x 12 Hex-Head Socket Cap Screws
2x M3 Nylock Nuts
4x M3 Nuts
1x M6 x 16 Button-Head Socket Cap Screw

Part 1 - Extruder Removal and Relocation
1.) disassemble the Rep2x's extruder down to just the plastic carriage
2.) remove the two flat head socket screws from the extruder and spin 180 degrees and remount using the same screws; do the same for the second extruder
3.) use a M5 tap or carefully thread the quick connectors into the filament openings on the top of the extruder holder (makerbot_ext.stl)
3.) attach the "flipped" extruders to the extruder holder (makerbot_ext.stl) using four M3 x 8 screws
4.) remove the cable tie mount from back of the Rep2x; mount the new extruder assembly to the Rep2x using the same hole; replace the factory screw with a M6 x 16. The extruder motors rest directly on the frame of the Rep 2x

Part 2 - Hotends
1.) refer to the E3Dv6 instructions to wire hotends. The Rep 2x can't use the thermistors that come in the kits; just thread the factory thermocouples from the Rep 2x into the E3D's heater block instead
2.) use a small screw to attach the endstop to the side of the holder
3.) add four M3 nuts to the recesses on the back of the hotend holder (hotend_holder.stl); drop the two hotends into the holder and fix in place using two of the (mount.stl) parts. Bolt together using four M3 x 25 screws and M3 washers.
4.) using screws from the kit, attach the fans to the fan ducts; keep track of left and right. snap/push on fan ducts to the heatsinks......when mounted correctly the ducts angle away from each other
5.) drop two M3 Nylocks into the recesses of the holder; mount the holder complete with fan ducts to the Rep2x's x-carriage using two M3 x 12 screws
6.) route wires between fan ducts then use a cable tie to attach control wires to the wire holding post that came with your rep 2x. Attach the wire at the extruder holder using a cable tie as well. You may need to adjust the nylon wire shroud to gain some length to attach it to the hotend holder

NOTE: You cannot use thermisters with the rep2x.....you need a k-type thermocouple. There are two different versions of the e3dv6 kits; the older kits come with thermisters and have a threaded mount. You can use the factory thermocouples from your rep2x in this case. The newer kits have a cartridge sensor that is held by a set screw; make sure you get the K-type cartridge.

NOTE: There are two files for the extruder holder, one is for aluminum extruders (alum_ext.stl) and one is for the factory MB extruders (makerbot_ext.stl)

you can get the aluminum extruders here:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Makerbot-Replicator-2X-Extruder-Upgrade-Filament-Drive-Build-Plate-Glass-/141896285178?hash=item2109ad7bfa:g:Mi8AAOSwwbdWMSx8

Only the ducts need supports when printing

IMPORTANT! You may have to adjust your extrusion multiplier.....this can fluctuate between different filaments......even a simple color change can affect this.
If you get any stringing, increase your retraction distance in small increments until it disappears. You may need to adjust your retraction speed as well.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Huxley

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%-35%

Notes:

ABS

comments.text: E3D V6 is not an upgrade for Replicator stock, it's a downgrade. Bowden is an upgrade though.
comments.author: 3Dpassion

comments.text: Hi, could you provide a link to the mounting bracket for the cooling duct? Thanks.
comments.author: quemazon

comments.text:
i updated my hotend using this and also added the pla fan like pictured .
i have also updated to the duetwifi board and the pt100 temp sensors .
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text: This is a well designed mod! Question about the motors mounting. Currently if i don't want to cross my bowden tubes my extruder is going backwards. How did you switch that around?
comments.author: Tmallard

comments.text: You probably swapped the motors instead of just spinning them 180. Easiest thing to do is mark the direction they spin on the motor. Then you can swap, flip, or whatever to get the proper direction. You should be able to run without the tubes crossed then.
comments.author: Tmallard

comments.text: If you are having trouble fitting the wires between the heatsinks, you can trim off the inside corners of the fan duct to get more room.
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: what offsets are you guys using for the x offset ?
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text: I designed the bracket so that it matches the factory positions, so you shouldn't need to adjust your offset. I didn't on mine, but it comes down to how well the bracket was printed. You can run the built in calibration to help find the right offset.
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text:
i did run the built in calibration and it printed the lines . i chose the correct numbers .
but it changed the offset to like 3200.34 thats crazy they are not that far apart
and a setting like that causes all sorts of grinding .
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: The default units for Simplify3d are in mm/min whereas software like Makerware uses mm/sec. You can change that in Simplify3d under tools>options. I haven't had to set any x offset so I am not sure what is going on in your situation. I looked up the default x offset using proftweak and I can't even find a setting for x-offset so I am assuming that it is built into the firmware.
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text:
after installing i get a error on power up . it says :
tool 0 failure temp reads out of rang check wiring .
tool 1 failure temp reads out of rang check wiring .
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text:
you just need to reverse the thermocouple wires; they are polarity dependent
also make sure you got the k-type thermocouples(has a nylon shroud over the wires).....the default kit comes with a thermistor(straight wires, no shroud)
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text: so yours had blue wire coming out of the cartridge and was about 3 inches of wire with a black plug on it ?
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: You got the wrong sensor; that is the thermistor. If you scroll down on that link you posted, you will see a youtube video that shows the different sensors. You need a k-type thermocouple; it will have a white nylon shroud over the wires.
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text:
lol they dont ask which one you want and i ordered directly from the link provided ..
thanks for replying
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: anyone know what firmware changes or changes in simplify3d need to be made when doing this mod ?
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text: No special firmware is needed; you will probably need to adjust you retraction distance and maybe retraction speed to avoid stringing.
comments.author: gurusonwheels

comments.text: If you have been getting some stringing between travel moves simply increase your retraction distance and speed.
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: What material do you recommend printing this with?  Will the temperature of the heatsink affect the plastic?  If I missed it in the instructions I apologize.
comments.author: nvchad2

comments.text: I did mine in regular ABS. I would recommend using a low warp ABS if you have it. Any high temp rigid filament will probably work fine. PLA will definitely not work.....at least not for long. The heatsinks will never even come close to the melting point of ABS as long as you don't have a fan failure. So far I have put about 100 hours on since the modification and haven't seen any cracking or noticeable warp.
comments.author: nvchad2

comments.text: Ok perfect, thanks for the response.  We're trying out HIPS since we have some at work that we'll never use.  Coming out great so far, only the ducts left to print.  I'll be sure to post some photos once we have it all set up.
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: Hello,
comments.author: Tinkyu

comments.text: You don't need to, the holder positions are equal distances in the z-axis. As long as your bed is good and flat dual extrusion is not really an issue. I have done quite a few dual prints so far with no problems. You definitely want to get a good quality print for the holder. A warped part could cause the z positions to be off.
comments.author: Tinkyu

comments.text: Yes, i know that they are leveld, but it would be nice to have that option just in case it was needed... until now i dident see a design with that possibility!
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: I agree, it would be nice to have the option. Getting the precision adjustment in the z-axis would be difficult to do with printed parts and is probably still a job for aluminum. Sure wish I had a CNC mill in my basement!
comments.author: Tinkyu

comments.text: Felixre7 used a paper shim under one of the mounts to the x-carriage to help with leveling the extruders. This would technically tilt the extruder but in such a tiny increment it probably won't have any negative effect.
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: Figured it out! Check for the new stls just posted!
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text:
thanks for your work cadsys!
it took a few minutes to figure out the difference to the old holder. you just reduced the height of the inner holder part.
i guess this should work fine because the power of the screws is enough to hold the hotend in place even without fixing in Z-direction.
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text: Let me know how that works; I haven't had a chance to test it myself. I am relying on the clamping force of the mount to keep the hotend in place so their is the possibility that it could shift in Z.......I think it's strong enough.....let me know if you get any shiftage.
comments.author: OsterNikolaus

comments.text:
another idea: until now i am using two ball bearing 12 v fans 40x40x10 mm series connected so i get the 24 volts needed.
i think it would improve your PLA cooling when you use one fan for each noozle. when the left extrufer fan is running the PLA fan automatically is running too.
let me know what you are thinking about this.
comments.author: OsterNikolaus

comments.text: I am currently using this cooler http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:228055; I like the design and just re-installed it after I made all the changes to the carriage. I haven't had a chance to print with PLA yet, but I definitely think one fan per nozzle would be a great idea.
comments.author: OsterNikolaus

comments.text: Did you print a different bracket for mounting that fan duct?
comments.author: cadsys

comments.text:
Yes it's actually from an older modification I did. You can find it here....http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:627617
I just flipped the bracket around and attached the cooling duct using two screws. It wasn't really designed for this use; I am planning on designing something better for that purpose. If you do use the bracket I would recommend using a piece of double sided tape to keep it from popping out of place.

comments.text: I have not used PLA yet; I would recommend adding an active cooling fan if possible.

comments.text:
hey cadsys,
could you please post a link to all the electronics used? i got a replicator 2X and it wont print with PLA for over 15 minutes without troubles.
i love the idea to banish the extruders to the edge. it should be much easier to maintain all the parts when they are seperated. the original setup is very cramped.
thank you very much for your work!
comments.author: OsterNikolaus

comments.text:
No special electronics are required, you simply need an E3dv6 kit; I got mine here:
https://www.matterhackers.com/store/printer-accessories/e3d-all-metal-v6-hotend-full-kit-1.75mm-universal-bowden-24v
you want the type-k thermocouple when you order the cartridge style sensors
I also recommend upgrading to the 40w heaters as well, they are found here:
https://www.matterhackers.com/store/printer-accessories/e3d-heater-cartridge-24v

thank you for the help! i will order both parts.

comments.text: oops! thanks for the correction, I changed the link to the 24v
comments.author: OsterNikolaus

comments.text: I also would like to know if this upgrade was worthwhile, i´ve tried to upgrade my replicator 2x so much but my extruders are shit, they will always jam if the print is 3 hours or more, little stuff its ok, but its impossible to do long runs.
comments.author: acereto

comments.text:
this mod is very worthwhile.
i have ordered the electronics (hotend full kit + 40 watt heaters) directly from china for 30 euros or someting. yesterday i just finished a 16 hours print without any problems. without the mod i was not able to print a thing over 10 minutes because the original hotend cooling setup is just not working crap.
comments.author: acereto

comments.text: The E3D hotends are far superior to the factory ones. You can print at higher temps allowing you to print with materials like nylon etc. Removing the extruder motors from the carriage reduces weight and therefore reduces mechanical feedback. This may not be as big of a deal with the rep2 since it only has one extruder.
comments.author: cadsys

description.text: This is a mold to make the most desirable part of a chocolate bunny. If you want to make an entire bunny make http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17507 Enjoy...

Print out both sides of the mold. You will need to brush the mold with acetone abs mixture so that the chocolate will not get caught in the crevices. You can use rubber bands to hold both sides of the mold together. Be sure to temper your chocolate. After chocolate is tempered scoop into plastic bag, and cut the corner of the bag off so you can inject the chocolate into the mold. Let harden then remove the yummy little bunny ear. For tips on working with chocolate
see http://www.marthastewart.com/267061/tempering-chocolate

comments.text:
Hey there! thanks for sharing... Is the chocolate easy to unmold...? do you apply any liquid to the mold to make the unmolding easier?
thks!
comments.author: lun_c

comments.text: I need this I LOVE CHOCOLATE
comments.author: kittycat123

comments.text: Is this safe? I have seen comments on other things such as cups and shot glasses here that suggest that you should not be consuming food or drink from things that you print.
comments.author: DigitalBytes

comments.text: ABS plastic is food safe.  ABS is the same type of plastic that water pipes are made from.  You want to make sure you fill in the crevices with ABS acetone mixture to prevent bacterial accumulation,  and making it washable.
comments.author: DigitalBytes

comments.text: I disagree. Sewer pipes are made from Abs. Water pipes aren't even made from PVC. They have to use CPVC which is specifically designed to not leech contaminants.

description.text:
I made this case as I found all the cables involved in connecting the programmer extremely messy. I bought the programmer from china at a ridiculous price (I know it is not the original, but for me its jut fine).
This is the link from where I bought it : http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-PICKIT3-Programmer-PIC-ICD2-PICKit-2-PICKIT-3-Programming-Adapter-Universal-Programmer-Seat/1291703648.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.112.E4MobM
I’m quite sure they are all the same size so if you get a different one it should fit anyway.
I had to do some soldering in order to make it all fit. There were only 6 wires that had to be soldered (the ICSP connector from the PicKit 3 to the relative header of the zif socket).
Now all I need to do before using it is to plug in the USB cable and I’m ready to go.
If you have any questions, please leave them in the comment section below.
Please like if you find this helpful.

Printer:

Cubicon Style

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

10%

Notes:

You might need supports for the mini USB hole if your printer is bad at bridging. For my printer it was not needed

MAKE SURE TO: Build them with the opening facing up!  
NEW: I added another model, which contains holes, spaced to allow 9 average sized screw drivers to fit. If you need them bigger, you can easily drill them out to w/e size you wish. Otherwise, edit w/ 3d program.   
INFO: Using the same slot design as my "hangable rods", I've made a hangable tool cup, for holding screw drivers, pens, or other random stuff.

MAKE SURE TO: Build them with the opening facing up!  
I've successfully printed one. Use external or full support for the slot nubs. I ran out of plastic at about 75%, but otherwise would've been good.  
Support: Yes/Full

title: Bowden Mount for Greg's Wade's Extruder

description.text: This Thing is for mounting Greg's Accessible Wade's Extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6713) to extruded aluminum. Really, though, it can be mounted to anything you want. All the holes are sized perfectly for M3 bolts. I made it because I am using this extruder as a bowden on my Kossel Mini. I was having a lot of trouble using the default Kossel Mini extruded modified to use 3mm filament. So I wanted to use a geared one. The hole for the filament is sized perfectly for a pneufit connector that facilitates 3mm filament. Or you can do what I did and just trap a couple of nuts threaded onto the bowden tube in between the mount and the extruder itself. It works fantastically.

comments.text: Any way this mount can be modified to work with 1.75 mm filament ?

author: HCP

title: Hose Holder for Beer Brewing Kettle

description.text:
I've had an issue with the hose not beeing where it should be when it should be and this 3D printed holder makes the whole process a lot simpler. I used to secure the hose with duct tape and weights, but it never held the warm hose for long, and eventually it spilled the mash out.

See it in action here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FhXi4orzDi4

I'm using a 36L kettle I bought from Bryggselv.no:
https://www.bryggselv.no/kjeler/400384/kjele-36l-med-kuleventil

Bryggselv.no also have 50L, 78L and 98L kettles and if the handles are the same this holder will fit fine.

The hose holder is a two part assembly. The hose fits into the white 3D printed tube which guides and holds the hose securely. The tube fits into the holder which snaps onto the kettle handle neatly.

description.text:
A collection of replacement pipe stems, including :

Peterson pipe stem, since they are rather difficult to get a hold of without buying a new pipe and I have a habit of chewing through mine.

Standard straight stem

A squared base stem that requires a metal threaded piece, this can be inserted by heating up the metal piece with a soldering iron and then inserting into the base.

A new 90 degree and 60 degree P-Lip one with a straight hole and another with a spiraled interior to allow for more cooling.

Needs to be printed at high quality to avoid air flowing through the plastic instead of the hole.

Update: Added a version for filters with a larger opening at the base.

Update: Added more styles of Pipe Stems

Update: Added a new style, with straight internal hole and a spiraled one.

title: Carrera Go 1:43 Slotcar BMW X3 Chassis with slide guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement chassis for the original one.
The original one has a simple pin for the slot and a magnet, so that it doesn't slide.

This is a chassis for a slide guide which allows you to drive over obstacles and slide.
It is designed for the Ninco slide guide 80104

Here you can find the parts for the VW Touareg Dakar
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1735188

Videos on Youtube
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OcNV0RwdAtk
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JPuhrFuYETk

Instructions

Print every part once.

You have to cut the original pin from the body so that there is enough space for the slide guide.

Glue BMW_chassis_part1 and BMW_chassis_part2 together.
To mount the BMW_guide_mount to the chassis, I use a needle.

Use a spring from a pen to push the guide_mount with the slide guide to the rails when driving over obstacles. Cut a small part out of it and try how it fits and works.

There is an extra hole in the chassis for the LED from the decoder. I modified all my cars with the decoder from the 1:32 Carrera Digital cars.

Parts to print

1x BMW_chassis_part1
1x BMW_chassis_part2
1x BMW_front_wheel_mount
1x BMW_rear_wheel_mount
1x BMW_guide_mount
1x BMW_motor_mount
1x BMW_pin

This chassis is designed for the Ninco slide guide 80104
http://www.nincoshop.de/ninco-80104-leitkiel-standard-mit-schleifer-4-x-neu-ovp.html

10x M2 screws
I use this one http://www.banggood.com/200pcs-M2-Allen-Bolt-Hex-Socket-Round-Cap-Head-Screw-Assortment-Kit-Set-Black-p-1041363.html?p=OF26119123132014119R

1x M3 10mm screw to mount the Chassis to the pin

title: The Whoopinator- FPV Quad Camera Mount

description.text:
Inspired by the “Tiny Whoop” low cost FPV quadcopter, this mount allows you to quickly add an FX798T camera to any drone able to carry a 6g payload.

This design came about because we have a small, ladies FPV drone racing club we're trying to get “off the ground” (LOL) here in Shenzhen. I'm trying to get more women and girls interested in the hobby as a gateway to Making. (Flying leads to crashing, crashing leads to fixing and a desire to create improvements.)

$100+ FPV drones are awesome but most of us can’t really drop that kind of money on a hobby and can't afford to crash a drone that costs that much while learning, so to keep the hobby accessible we’ve been focusing on stock micro quads and indoor parking lot racing (underground parking lots mostly). We’ve only got a few cameras and a kind of random collection of quads so I came up with this rig so we could quickly attach a FX798T to whatever we have that day and get racing.

The design is based on Oscar Liang’s “Whoopee” VTX holder. Print is one piece and somewhat more robust since many of our races turn into dogfights:-) Total weight of FX798T, holder and zip-tie is >6g. We’ve been mostly strapping them to JJRC H8 Mini’s but it fits just fine of my Syma X5C as a trainer quad.

There are two versions, regular and a strong one with an extra protective ring. I use the strong version since I crash…a lot :-P

I’ll post my FPV display solution soon...

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15mm

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:

ABS or PLA is fine. I’ve never had one break since the micro quads weight so little.

title: Volvo Brake Piston Tool C30, S40, V50, C70 etc

description.text:
This is a tool to retract the brake caliper piston on various Volvo and Ford cars.

Use with a 30mm socket apply pressure (approx 20Kg / 200N required) while turning clockwise to get the caliper to retract .

Requires two M3 hex head bolts for the pins (approx 20mm long). Screw them in, but leave them a few mm proud for a better fit.

I printed in PLA @ 30% infill.

Inspired by thing:216291.

title: BF4 LS06 Style Suppressor for G&G; M4 Combat Machine

description.text:
This is my final design for my G&G Raider, i modified my original suppressor (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1655586) a bit further.
I used Battlefield 4's "look" of their LS06 suppressor, for my final design.
There are 3 parts to this design, the silencer only, which can be used, as per the original design, on its own (just follow the link and instructions), the base, and pins. The base i design to slide into the picatinny rail system of the raider, as my previous design only attached to the barrel (inner), and it felt a bit flimsy. This design has to "ears" that slide in wher the original outer barrel screwed in. I left 4m holes in these "ears" so the same screws can be used to fasten the base of the silencer, to the raider. Both base and silencer has 2 pin holes, these are for the 4 halve pins that come with the design. They are to add a little bit more stability to the silencer, and also to attache the silencer to the base.

Not to sound like a Youtube channel, but please dont forget to like the design

title: Semi-Tube & Tube 'BOB'
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
(Learn more about the story of the Semi-Tube Slingshot and its performance at http://www.slingshotforum.com. Search for 'aiping'!)

Same like Semi-Tube Slingshot: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1589828
PLUS THE LITTLE FEATURE TO CLIP-IN SINGLE or LOOPED TUBES
IMPORTANT: Please secure the Clip-Slot with 5+ tight windings of office rubber
in the Semi-Tube groove. (Like in the main picture the green office rubber)

Feature Summery

  • Oval fork cones allow to attach flat bands up to 9 cm wide
    Detailed procedure you can find here:

http://slingshotforum.com/topic/50425-semi-tube-slingshot-pouchband-attachment/

Tests with multilayer TBB (blue&black) showed that single layer TBS/TBG should be no problem.

  • Tube channel with clip slot for single or looped tubes. IMPORTANT: Please secure
    the Clip-Slot with 5+ tight windings of office rubber in the Semi-Tube groove.
    (Like in the main picture the green office rubber)

  • Steel ball dispenser up to 13 mm, prepared to glue in a magnetic disk diameter 10 mm / hight 5 mm

  • Flashlight holder diameter 14 mm (don't use a laser for aiming !!!)

  • Slingbow-Plugin available: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1709207

  • Tilted fork to support a straight fist

Warning! This slingshot is only for experienced shooters, draw at least 5 times effective
band length.

Use of this slingshot at your own risk, especially full butterfly!

LEGAL&SECURITY: Only print and use this slingshot according to the legal regulations of your country. NEVER EVER shoot at humans, even not point and aim. ALWAYS use protective glasses. I strongly suggest a catch box made at least from 15 mm plywood, 20 cm dense plastic foam or 1 mm steel. Don't shoot at concrete or brick walls due to violent ricochets, which can seriously injure yourself or bystanders, of course damage windows, flat screens etc. Only shoot as far as you are able to see, aim AND hit your target.

Slingshot orientation: Ball dispenser AWAY from your body, touching the inner index finger. The flat bands are directed from the grove to the end of the fork cones. This version is for hold left and draw right handed.

Printer:

Da Vinci 1.0

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

50% +

Notes:

ABS !!!!

Furthermore, I stepped on the Slingshot (80 kg +) without any
suspicious noise or cracking. So infill of 50% should be fine for
a draw of 20 kg. If you draw more or widen the tube channel
than I suggest 100% infill. The clip slots are printed differently wide
due to the Slicer or Printer?. Egalize the smaller slot carefully
with sandpaper

author: APing

description.text: I am a person who seems to misplace things quite often, so I designed a holder for my scraper that attaches to my printer (and could attach to others). This may need to be sanded a little bit depending on how far your blade sticks out from the holder.
Scale this part up or down to fit the blade of your desire. I also printed this part at 100% infill, but would be fine at 25% or even lower.

This is a case for Raspberry Pi 3.

Thanks to leave a LIKE.
Even a little Tip is highly appreciated.

Since i am fascinated from the small size of the raspberry pi, I wanted to keep the case as small as possible.

Furthermore I wanted to ensure accessibility of the GPIO´s, the flat cable connections and all of the ports.

In addition I wanted to have various mounting options.
You have a flat bottom surface so that you can simply use double sided tape.
You have mounting holes in the bottom so that the case can be screwed.
And on top you have "Quick mounting" devices. Once the "quick mounting devices" are screwed, you can install and remove the raspberry pi easily without using any tools.
You can use them... but you don´t have to.

For designing the Case I used a 3D Model of the raspberry itself so the case actually fits very well.

please note:
Since each printer has its own tolerances and therefore the print quality might vary from machine to machine - you can slightly rework the print with some sandpaper at the following sections:

  • the 4 Push pins: The fit should be tight. But in case you need too much forces to push the top into the bottom (danger of destruction) please slightly rework with sandpaper.

  • the wall mounts: The fit should be tight. But in case you need too much forces to push the case into the wall mounts please slightly rework with sandpaper.

Print recommendation:
I recommend high infill percentage.
(>80%).
Layer Height = 0.1mm to 0.15mm
Supports are not required.

Cherz

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.15

Infill:

80%

title: Wheel for R/C Slowflyer / Shockflyer (parametric, OpenSCAD)

description.text:
After the wheels of my shockflyer broke I needed a better replacement. This is the fully customizable replacement part, designed to be light and strong. It can be adapted to many setups (diameter of wheel and axis, height of hub and spokes etc.).

Default version (as the uploaded SCAD) is for a 3mm CFK axis, different ones can just be created by using customizer, by changing the parameter "dwelle".

I use them in an original "Ikarus Shockflyer" for over a year now and they work very fine.

description.text:
A simple tool to speed up your unloading of mid and low cap magazines. It just slips on to the top of a bb bottle then you can press your magazines into the top to unload them back in to the bottle with no spillage.

I've added a version 2 of this which has a better fit in to the magazine. I've only tested it with M4 magazines atm.

author: Kumardebu

print_settings.Notes:: If you can can print at 100 microns for even better results.

title: LM8UU and LM8LUU Hybrid PTFE bearing

description.text:
Summary

I have been playing around with bearings designs lately and thought I would share this latest hybrid 8mm bearing. The video at the bottom demonstrates the finished product on a 8mm linear shaft.

https://youtu.be/HjRh_Fa9G2I

It makes use of commonly available PTFE tubing for the area which is in contact with the linear shaft, combined with a printable bearing housing. This has quite a few advantages; as it's light weight, PTFE has an extremely low friction coefficient and if the tube wears over time it can simply be replaced, without the need to dismantling the linear shaft assembly.

The PTFE tube only protrudes out from the bearing wall by about 100~150 microns, which is enough to provide a glide surface with very little friction. The 3rd image illustrates the overlap of the tubing from the bearing inner wall.

Part number and variants

I try to design things with fairly high tolerances and I know from a previous bearing a few people had issues printing, this time I have made 10 variants of each bearing size. Additionally I have made 5mm test samples of each variant, allowing a smaller test prototype to be made a tested.

The part numbers should help to identify them and can be broken down as follows:

Part number: 24mm_Bearing_4xPTFE_8.2mmx2.2mm
Bearing length (2 variants): 24mm (LM8UU) or 45mm (LM8LUU)
Number of 2mm PTFE runners (2 variants): 4 or 6
Inner diameter (3 variants): 8.2mm, 8.3mm and 8.4mm
2mm PTFE tube tolerance (3 variants): 2.2mm, 2.3mm and 2.4mm

Printing

The 8.2mm ID will give the tightest fit, then the 8.3mm and finally the 8.4mm I/D will be the loosest. There will also be a subtle variation in fit between say an 8.4mm I/D with 2.2mm tube room and a 8.4mm I/D with 2.4mm diameter. The effect of this variation will be down to your printers accuracy and the PTFE's actual O/D, as the PTFE tube might be a good fit, loose fit or very tight fit causing it to squeeze and deform slightly out through the gap in the wall facing the linear shaft. There is nothing to be done here due to the large number of possible tolerance variations, hence why I have tried to offer enough variants to cover the majority of cases.

I have made a few of these myself and found the 8.2mm was a little too tight, especially as the 2mm PTFE tubing I am using is approximately 2.1~2.25mm. For best results I would first measure your PTFE tubing and then start with the 8.3mm ID version. The 5mm test samples should make the process less painful, just bear in mind sliding 2mm PTFE tube into a 5mm sample is very easy compared to a 45mm length.

I made all my test print in PLA on a layer height of 200 microns with a 50% infill, for final production bearings I will use 100 microns and slow everything down to get the best results.

Future

Pending on the response to this I have some other ideas using this principle!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Wanhao Di3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 microns

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print for quality not speed I would say! I slow down my settings for parts for the printer, to improve the part quality which ultimately goes on to improve the quality of future prints.

The aim of these bearings is to reduce the weight of any moving parts and then ultimately allow for greater print speeds.

If you can can print at 100 microns for even better results.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/HjRh_Fa9G2I" ></iframe>

comments.text:
Not a very good idea. PTFE and of course in tube form is not suitable. People who thinks it is a good idea are welcome to say why and try :)
Igus sells a filament that works pretty well. Of course, no way to get a proper fit and surface quality by just printing. You have to make the parts oversized and adjust them. Files and reamers are cheap. Works fine, hold well. Friction coef is greater than PTFE but iglidur does'nt creep ! And simple SS rods supplied with most kits which are totally unsuitable for LM bearings are fine with these bushings.
Oh and no need to focus on standard LM form factors, just design the parts directly to accommodate the smaller bearing. For ex. for 8mm rods, proper sizes are OD 12mm L 12mm. I saved 80gr on my Prusa X carriage and 160g on my Y by just repalcing the LM!

comments.text: When I have made printed plastic bushings for drone projects ... I found I could control the internal clearance by intentionally designing the bushing too tight, then carefully heating the assembly (oven / heat gun), allowing some limited stress relaxation of the plastic .. if done right, a perfect fit can be achieved (until the bushing wears from use, of course).

Here is a basic filament holder and dust remover combo. I designed it to fit on top of my Aluminum Mendel, but it could be attached to virtually any printer (especially ones with aluminum extrusions).  
I cut a basic sponge to size and then poked a hole in it that lined up with the hole in the part. The filament runs smoothly through the sponge and filament guide hole.  
After a few test runs it seems to be doing its job, but I would love to hear your feedback.  
UPDATE:  
I noticed that the sponge was moving a little bit while printing and it was also getting dried out faster than what I anticipated. So I designed this lid to keep everything from moving and to also keep the moisture in the sponge for a longer period of time.

description.text: A grinning Jack-o'-Lantern you can make with with your Eggbot, says "Happy Halloween!" on the back. Text, crosshatched infill, and outline are all on separate layers. Font used for the text is Lunacy More. It can be found at Dafont http://www.dafont.com/lunacy-more.font

print_settings.Notes:: Just load the file, set Size X at 40mm (for double 20mm), then split them as two objects, and it should work easily. If anyone tries, be careful with your fingers when plugging

description.text:
You push and plug these two, and they're locked on all three axis. Well, that's the theory. It needs perfecting. It's particularly very resistant to being pulled out straight. I'm sure you could attach 20kg or 30kg easily. It works best with 20mm for each part, or 4cm total (~2.2cm when plugged). The utility is that you can add it to your 3D models, and then easily plug one in another. It kinda works at 10mm, but it's a bit flimsy. I'm a beginner modeler.

I admit that in small size it prints best if they're horizontally flat on the surface, as in the file, so it's a constraint on how it is placed on the model, unless you glue it afterward.

To unplug, remove one arm and twist the head out. I admit it's slightly annoying to unplug. I haven't thought much about it. But I think it's an interesting mechanism. I hope to see more of this kind of plugging mechanisms, exploiting the light flexibility of PLA. This probably doesn't work with ABS filament or such, it'd need adjusting, I made it for standard PLA.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Dagoma Discovery200

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Just load the file, set Size X at 40mm (for double 20mm), then split them as two objects, and it should work easily. If anyone tries, be careful with your fingers when plugging
I was inspired by the Cable Holder of Pataky3D

description.text:
I searched Thingiverse for a .338 and couldn't, so I decided to model one myself! I modelled a .338 Lapua round in Onshape. All dimensions should be accurate (apart from the bullet itself, as it varies). If it does not print well, I suggest splitting the model in a program like NetFabb and then gluing the pieces together.

The .338 Lapua is an interesting cartridge, as it offers the anti-personnel capabilites of a larger round such as a .50 BMG, but is lighter, thus a sniper can carry more.

Probably most notably used in the L115 (Accuracy International AWM) and by the British Armed Forces. It has seen use and is combat proven in many conflicts. The longest ever confirmed sniper kill was with this round, at 2,475m!

Have fun!

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Left to right: .50BMG, .338 Lapua Magnum (3D printed), .308 Winchester/7.62x51 NATO, .223rem/5.56x45 NATO 'Close' up

OnShape

OnShape is a free, cloud based CAD program that has very powerful capabilities.
https://www.onshape.com/

The project file is public! - https://cad.onshape.com/documents/98552d57f0299e1fdea9aa67/w/f2b999d6965205c13bd3cd98/e/6f9173b1a6646a706c5ed9e8

I always thought turks head rope work and jewelry was pretty neat.  So, I thought I'd try my hand at designing one.  I did this with Eureka a few minutes ago and took me about 10 minutes.  Most of the time was trying to figure out the angles and twist to get it looking like something.  I'll probably keep messing with it and will upload improvements.  
Warning:  I haven't printed this yet and it's diameter is 75mm, so it might be a bit large.  Play around with the sizing to make it fit you.  
I added the Eureka file so if someone has the software, they can see how I made it.  Notice the file size difference even though they are the EXACT same object. :)  
Update:  I made a slight modification and uploaded version 2 to change the weave pattern a little bit.  I like it better, but left the origninal to let you judge for yourself.

Slowbro from pokemon

http://www.thingiverse.com/Bisic/designs

title: GoPro Wanhao Prusa i3 Bed Mount

description.text:
GoPro mount for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Monoprice Maker Select / Cocoon Create.

The bed mount uses M3 bolts and nuts to secure it to the print bed but this may not be necessary depending on how tight a fit you get on the bed. I haven't used any and it holds perfectly.

If you make one, please post pics! Pic courtesy Jens Christensen

https://youtu.be/n156ClKN_Yg

https://youtu.be/XDpD5-Sdm1M

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You should use ABS or materials with a higher glass temperature than the print you are going to be doing. I used PLA and while it does work, it is not as tight as I would like.

Print the way you see best. I have printed with supports and it worked perfectly. YMMV.

description.text: ship

title: E3D Titan Bracket for Vellemann K8200

description.text:
This thing is a mounting bracket to use the E3D Titan extruder on a Velleman K8200 printer. I printed mine with 40% infill, 0.8mm shells in black PLA. It does require 4 mounting screws, two from below, two at the back of the bracket. The rest of printer needs major changes:

The layer cooling fan no longer fits, I use two extra 40mm fans left and right to the E3Dv6 hotend connected to a fan holder for the normal cooling fan mounted on the hotend heat-sink.

The whole Z axis assembly needs to be moved about 4cm to the back of the printer.

I also had to lower the Z axis assembly. This only works because I use a IR mini sensor board as Z endstop, the original Z endstop assembly does not longer fit.

This untested design is intended to be mounted with the motor screws on a BoltRC Tanto 150 microquad. This design has not yet been printed but seems to pass most online dimension checks. I'll have it printed shortly and make changes as needed.

The material should be something dense and slick. This is not designed to soften landings but is instead designed to allow the quad to slide on pavement. I primarily fly my Tanto around my house and want some protection for when I scrape the sidewalks, driveway, and cul-de-sac pavement.

Modelled a 5.56x45 NATO round in Onshape. All dimensions should be accurate (apart from the bullet itself, as it varies). If it does not print well, I suggest splitting the model in a program like NetFabb and then gluing the pieces together.

The 5.56x45 NATO is amongst the most used rounds in the modern military. It see's use in AR15 style rifles, such as the M4A1 Carbine in the US Military, as well as in the British SA80 firearm family, in rifles such as the L85A2. It is a small round, thus light, making it good for the average soldier. They are capable of carrying many rounds when in service, each round capable of being fatal.

The more common civilian version is the .223 Remington. In many ways, the rounds are alike, in general size, but the military 5.56x45 NATO is loaded at a higher pressure and has a faster muzzle velocity.

Have fun!

I am constantly digging through my desk drawer to find the small screw drivers or my tweezers or ... So I designed this tool holder for the tools I use the most. I printed this with my I3 and entered custom code to change the filament to black to get the letters to stand out. In the file I uploaded, I increased the size of the font for the tweezers because that obviously didn't print out right. But it works, and now everything has a home and is easy to find. As always, I've included the Sketchup file in case anyone wants to make modifications for their own tools. And for the record, it's a tight fit for the drivers. I made them .4mm wider than the drivers, but they took a little work to get them in and out initially.

title: Tetrahedral racks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Four identical parts go together to make a symmetric sliding mechanism. It is a difficult puzzle to put them together, and even more difficult to have them slide together so that they all have the same offset relative to each other.

This worked well printed vertically with no support.

This is joint work with Saul Schleimer.

Available from Shapeways at http://shpws.me/MCng

comments.text: This printed very well for me apart from some vibration due to the racks extending into free space. My biggest issue is figuring out how to get them together. Any tips for a newbie? I should have known how hard it would be due to the problems I had getting the boromean hairpins together and that was only 3... Figured the tetrahedral model would work better due to the smoother surface due to lack of support material.
comments.author: Darkwraith

comments.text: Very nice. Any chance of making caps for the free ends?
comments.author: sberfield

comments.text: These are solid, for better fdm printing. So there are no holes to plug a cap into. I guess one could print a solid cap, and drill holes into the cap and the rods, and glue with a pin?
comments.author: sberfield

comments.text: You could design in holes in the ends of the racks that a spiked end cap could align with. I'd probably just leave it as it is as the ends of the racks vibrate a lot for me during printing and getting accurate holes would be difficult. Plus the walls would be thin then. Better off drilling and pinning but would be nice to have the end cap model by itself. Quick workaround for people is to sink the rack end through the print bed in your slicer thus only getting the end cap.
comments.author: henrysegerman

comments.text: Makes sense. Very nice piece of work. Your stuff is amazing.
comments.author: henrysegerman

comments.text: Glad you like it!
comments.author: sberfield

I have designed my own quadcopter frame which is fully 3D-printable.
This quad is to be used with the following components:

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__16719__NTM_Prop_Drive_28_Series_Accessory_Pack.html

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__25082__NTM_Prop_Drive_28_26_1000KV_235W_short_shaft_version_.html

http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__42715__Q_Brain_4_x_25A_Brushless_Quadcopter_ESC_2_4S_3A_SBEC.html

https://hobbyking.com/en_us/8045-sf-props-2pc-cw-2-pc-ccw-rotation.html

The chassis can be assembled using m3 bolt and nuts, assembly is prity straight forward. The propeller covers are optional. They do make the quad look bigger and thus more impressive ;-)

I have already printed mine except for the dome part. I want to print the dome of natural PLA so I can make some fancy light effects with RGB LEDs

author: EvilTeach

print_settings.Notes:: ABS recommended. Higher infill value is preferred to provide better strength.

description.text:
4 cell AA battery case with built in spring structure.

This is designed for building 4-cell AA sized battery packs without soldering batteries together while still remain as slim as possible in order to fit battery chamber in devices designed for factory produced battery packs.

Each end has a partially connected ring structure that function as a spring to ensure firm contact with the battery. And in the center there are 4 5mm wide slots for you to secure wirings for the battery connection.

All you need in addition to the printed objects are a couple rubber bands that holds the assembly together, and some wiring for connecting batteries. 5mm wide solder tabs are preferred as connection material but you can use anything from copper wire to even 5mm wide aluminium bands cut from soda cans.

If you choose to use soda cans, be sure to remove coating on both sides to allow conductivity. You can do that by either burning it lightly or some sanding.

I designed this quickly because I had no O-Rings available to do vibration dampening on a few builds I had recently done. They seem to work well. They are M3 size and available in 1mm, 2mm, and 3mm. These should be sufficient for your dampening needs. I haven't needed the 3mm yet but if you create a "fast" profile on your printer it's a <5 minute print to print a few of these.

Special thanks to https://www.thingiverse.com/eveloso/ for assisting me with learning how to line models up on Tinkercad.

This is my first 3d print project :).

It uses a raspberry pi zero, running retropie.

Most of the inspiration for this came from Adafruit's PiGRRL and
Sudomod's Game Boy Zero. While designing this, I wanted to keep the look and feel of the classic SNES controller.

My google photo album with all the pics while designing/building it.
https://goo.gl/photos/DuyE2tGNVcjDhsfM6

parts:

  • Raspberry Pi Zero
  • 3.5in tft screen
  • 10 x 6mm tactile switches
  • 2 x 12mm tactile switches
  • adafruit PowerBoost 1000c
  • Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 2500mAh
  • Adafruit Mono 2.5W Class D Audio Amplifier
  • 8 ohm speaker
  • IOGEAR 4-Port USB 2.0 Hub
  • Panel Slide Switch
  • 50k ohm Wheel Potentiometer 16 x 2mm
  • 5-Pin Stereo 3.5mm Socket Audio Connector
  • PCB Boards
  • audio filter: 10uF cap, .033uF cap, 150 ohm resistor, 270 ohm resistor
  • case screws: 2 x #4 -40 x 3/4" screw & nut
  • buttons screws: 6 x #2 -56 x 3/8" screw & nut

UPDATE(12/18/16): Just uploaded new buttons and dpad with chamfered edges. The first versions hurt my fingers after playing for a while.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Yes

10%

comments.text: I have never seen one in person, so I can't be sure. But by looking at images, it is probably smaller. It is really simple to get some protoboards and cut them to the needed size. Then soldering them is also really simple. If you need any advice, feel free to ask.
comments.author: grizzlygypsy84

comments.text: Great project, Looks like almost exatly what I'm going to try to make but with a Pi3 and Pimoroni Hyperpixel screen (no spare gpio so will hack a snes usb controller). Will take some time to get eveything to fit nice but will post a remix when done
comments.author: JamieP

comments.text: Thank you so much! This was my very first 3D model project ever, so it pretty rough lol. I have been thinking about making a revision two, but just haven't made the time.
comments.author: JamieP

comments.text: Now this is a cool thing. I was imagining something similar, but no screen. My old man loves retro games, so was considering Pi Zero in an SNES pad. Does this wire all the buttons to the TFT like the Pi Grrl Zerp?
comments.author: Arusia

comments.text: I used one of these screens and modified it to work with 5v. The video input just wires to the composite pin on the pi zero.
comments.author: Arusia

comments.text: You misunderstand. I don't want a screen in it at all. I'm looking for something he could just plug into a tv.
comments.author: robertguy

comments.text: LOL my bad I did read that wrong. All the buttons are wired to the GPIO like all of the pi grrls. You should be able to make a little controller with the pi zero inside pretty easy. You could even modify an existing controller and wires it to the GPIO or use USB pretty easy too. I have seen a few people online do similar projects.

comments.text: It works great for me! I choose to put the headphone jack before the amplifier so that it wouldn't be too loud. I tried it after the amplifier and it was way too loud for me. I went with a 50k pot bc of the speaker, 10k wouldn't let me lower the speaker volume all the way. The headphone only uses about 1/3 the range of the 50k pot. After about 1/3, the headphone are essential off. If I was only using the headphone I would have just went with the 10k pot. comments.text: They can work the same. Those are stereo amps , did you want to have two speakers?
comments.author: Firestw152

comments.text: Well no I only made one hole for the speaker in my 3d printed case. I thought it was impossible to have two speakers and a headphone jack on the pi zero.
comments.author: robertguy

comments.text: You can have stereo audio using two pwm pins and two audio filters. On the headphone jack pin 5 and 4 are connected and pin 3 and 2 are connect when no headphone is connected. So you put left on 2 and right on 5.
comments.author: Firestw152

comments.text: Oh ok but wouldnt that limit my GPI pins? Like if I do that then I can't have Right trigger or Left trigger? Or a hotkey button?
comments.author: robertguy

comments.text: So dpad is 4 pins, abxy is 4 pins, L&R is 2 pins and start and select is 2 pins. Then assuming you do stereo audio, you can use pins 13 and 18 (there is some alternate pins too, but I'm being too lazy to look it up though :P ). That makes a total of 14 pins used. If I recall correctly there is like 27 GPIO pins on the Pi. So you have PLENTY of room to add more buttons and have stereo audio. You just have to modify the code for the buttons a bit, but its super easy.
comments.author: Firestw152

comments.text: Well I already just made one hole for a speaker so im just gonna leave it mono for now. It sounds like the headphone jack isn't completely disconnecting when you plug in the headphone. I would recommend double checking your soldering and if that doesn't work, try another headphone jack. You could also try turning down the amplifier with the tiny screw (a trim pot) and see if that helps.

comments.text: its bc throughout my system, all the Grounds are the same. So there isn't an open circuit from not connecting that ground to the wheel pot. Systems with higher quality audio with isolate the audio portion from other parts to reduce noise in the audio. You can add the ground pin, but I don't believe it will improve or change anything.

new matter mod-t

20

2 mm shell

4 add decals (I lost the file for the ones in the photo(sorry)) and use paint pens for the sensor grid

author: alumin

print_settings.Notes:: The sides require supports.  Everything else should be printed without supports.
print_settings.Infill:: 50% or higher on sides, 20% on everything else

description.text:
This mounts an iPhone 6 to a tripod to make it easier to take 360 degree panoramas/photospheres using apps such as Google Streetview. The 360 degree views can then be shared on sites such as Facebook.

With this mount, the iPhone 6's camera is kept in the same place as it is tilted using this mount, or panned using the tripod. This minimizes distortion/discontinuities in the 360 degree panorama.

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm layer height

Infill:

50% or higher on sides, 20% on everything else

Notes:

The sides require supports. Everything else should be printed without supports.

Purchase some 1/4-20 hex nuts (they should fit on your tripod).

Print two sides, one base, one plug, and one of the phone holders. "Phone Holder 4mm Foam" leaves room for some foam (e.g. weatherstripping) on both sides of the phone. This keeps the phone snug. If you don't have any foam, print "Phone Holder No Foam" instead.

Assemble as shown below (the gray block represents the tripod). Insert the sides into the holes in the phone holder, then superglue the sides to the base. Superglue the hex nut and plug to the base.

After letting the glue dry, attach the mount to a tripod and insert the iPhone 6 upside down into the mount. This orientation keeps the camera in the same place as the phone is tilted.

description.text:
Nouvelle version de mon sabot de flash. Comme j'utilise mes flashs presque exclusivement en déporté grâce qu système de pilotage Nikon, j'ai besoin de fixer ceux-ci sur des pieds photos. Dans une ancienne version, j'avais imprimé directement le filetage a l'intérieur du sabot. Mais a la longue le filetage s'abîme. C'est pourquoi j'ai fait cette version avec un écrou prisonnier au pas "photo" (écrou 1/4 de pouce 20 filets au pouce). Je l'ai trouvé en France chez Harley Davidson ;-))

New version of a cold shoe for my flashes. As I use quite exclusively off-camera flashes with Nikon system of piloting, I need to fix these to foot photo. In a former version, I had printed directly the threading inside of the shoe. But due to using the threading gets damaged. That is why I made this version with a prisoner nut with the step "photo" (nut 1/4 inch 20 ; nets by inch). I found it in France at Harley Davidson ;-))

Printer:

Vertex K4800

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15 mm

Infill:

description.text:
The venturi water nozzle project can be used to demonstrate physics and engineering. A high speed jet of air creates low pressure suction which will suck water up through the connector and mix with the air stream to come out the nozzle.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vrLS9ymRUuw

Printer:

Generic Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed in several orientations to find the one that worked best for my printer. Use supports to help with the floating pieces before they get printed together.

Overview & Background
Venturi nozzles are a useful device for increasing air flow or creating a vacuum with a given high speed air source. They have several uses in aviation avionics, jet engines, jet water pumps, atomizers, just to name a few. Students can get hands on experience with a small scale 3D printed nozzle and learn the physics associated with the venturi effect. Bernoulli's principle and equation are stars in this project.

Accessories
The following materials and items can be helpful with this project.

  • compressed air source (could be air compressor, bicycle pump with a surge tank, other source?)
  • air hose with quick release ends
  • Pocket Blow Gun with Industrial Coupler (example: http://www.harborfreight.com/Pocket-Blow-Gun-with-Industrial-Coupler-68262.html)
  • water and open vessel
  • graduated cylinder to measure water
  • straw from fast food or your pantry
  • optional - 10' length of 1/4" vinyl tubing (check plumbing section of diy store)
  • calipers, rule, or tape to measure things
  • stop watch
  • protection gear - eye protection!! and any other gear that might be a good idea.

Objectives

  • Learn how to calculate moving air volume based on speed and cross section.
  • Learn how high speed air can create pressure differentials.
  • Learn how to utilize air pressure differential to create suction.
  • Learn how to test and calculate the suction pressure.

Audiences
Main application: High school physics, college physics lab, fluid dynamics.
Really any age could benefit from this project. The demonstration could enlighten all ages.

Subjects

  • Physics
  • Science
  • Mathematics
  • Engineering

Skills Learned (standards)

  • MP.4 - Model with mathematics. (HS-ETS1-1), (HS-ETS1-2), (HS-ETS1-3), (HS-ETS1-4)
  • RST.11-12.9 - Synthesize information from a range of sources (e.g., texts, experiments, simulations) into a coherent understanding of a process, phenomenon, or concept, resolving conflicting information when possible.

Lesson / Activity
Step 1 - Background Knowledge

  • Discuss Bernoulli's principle and equation.
  • Discuss nozzles.
  • Discuss Ventrui Effect through special nozzles.
  • Print and use the Water_Nozzle_cross_section for as a visualization aid.

Step 2 - Design and/or build
Option 1:

  • Have students design a ventrui nozzle and print it.

Option 2:

  • Print the nozzles I have in the thing files.

Step 3 - Practical testing
Option 1:

  • Assemble the parts as shown:
    Photo below
    Air source -> hose -> air gun -> water nozzle -> straw / tubing -> water vessel -> anemometer at outlet of nozzle (but you might wait for the anemometer)
    SAFETY NOTE: start with air gun in closed position and air source off if possible
  • Try it without water first.
  • Turn on air and gun (30 psi seems to work).
  • Measure air speed and take notes.
  • Turn off air and gun.
  • add measured amount of water to water vessel.
  • Turn on air and gun (30 psi seems to work).
  • Time the duration of operation.
  • Measure air speed and take notes.
  • Turn off air and gun.
  • Measure remaining water, or hopefully stop the time when vessel is empty.

Option 2:

  • Do above several times with different air pressures: 30 psi, 40 psi, 50psi, etc...

Option 3:

  • use length of 1/4" tubing and determine how much elevation head in inches of h2o you can achieve with this nozzle by elevating the nozzle until the flow from the vessel stops.

Option 4:

  • Skip measuring and demonstrate the nozzles ability to mist water.

Step 3 - Calculations

  • Calculate the air flow through nozzle.
  • Calculate the water flow through nozzle.
  • Calculate the water flow gained or lost at different operating pressures by the venturi nozzle.
  • If you did the range of psi tests, graph the results and determine the most efficient air pressure for this nozzle.
  • If you did the pressure head, calculate how many inches of h2o the system was able to achieve.

Step 4 - Review

  • Discuss applications where students might see them.
  • Discuss how students think they could use them in a new application.

Rubric

  • What is the velocity of the air for each nozzle?
  • What is the diameter of the outlet?
  • What is the volume air flow through the venturi nozzle without water?
  • What is the volume air flow through the venturi nozzle with water?
  • Did the air flow change? Why do you think it did or did not?
  • What is the suction pressure?

Tips & Tricks

  • It works! It sucks water quite efficiently!
  • Other fluids can work, or even granular material like sand.
  • I used fast food straws for the demo video. I tapered the fluid connection in the design to adapt a variety of tubing diameters. The tapered inlet may need a little attention to smooth it out depending on how you print it.
  • Some of the air gun holders might break off, doesn't effect performance noticeably.

Assets
I have included the water_nozzle_v3.f3d fusion 360 design file in the thing files. Modifications for other pipe sizes, nozzle sizes, blow guns, air sources, etc... could be made.

  • water_nozzle_v3.f3d
  • water_nozzle.stl
  • water_nozzle_section.stl

References

  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venturi_effect
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernoulli%27s_principle
  • https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/a-lip-smacking-look-at-the-day-that-drinking-straws-got-bigger/2013/07/07/f3fd8b8e-e584-11e2-aef3-339619eab080_story.html
Nozzle on Gun, straw in water, ready to plug together and spray water.

comments.text: Old fashion perfume atomizer with an air pump bulb work this way.  Sand / bead blasters work this way. Autobody paint guns and air brushes work like this. Any device that passes a high speed fluid (air in this case) by an orfice to create suction and subsequent mixing works this way.  If you capped off the suction side with a pressure gauge, then there are many more applications.
